lines.text: Who understands ANYONE these days... who WANTS to?
Gosh, I want to kiss you so bad, Dinky...
It's good to want things...
From a deep, immaculate kiss she spread her two ripe, dripping limbs and then I happened.
I beg your pardon.
And the moon throbbed and fought with an angry sun all that day and all that night. Until it forced me out.
Dinky!
Now I scald here... alone. Touch me. With your white words and your dead hands. Now before I freeze.
That'll be enough!
And become one of you.
DINKY!
You interrupted me.
I'm sorry if I embarassed you the other day. I kind of got carried away.
You embarassed yourself.
I'm going to laugh at you someday, Gerald Howells.
I don't think I understand, Dinky.
It's not for you to understand, really.

Starting tomorrow there will be hourly tours of Roxy Carmichael's birthplace. You'll see where Roxy slept and where she ate during her wonder years. You'll also see pictures of her beloved dog, Bonkers.
She loved that dog. She used to ride it. It was a big dog.
Dinky Dean Bossetti, is that the yellow sweater i bought for you last week? That was a thirty-two dollar sweater, missy, and you dyed it black, didn't you? After you promised me you wouldn't.
Correction. I didn't promise I wouldn't. I said I'd try not to.

[after Dinky has caused a scene at Roxy Carmichael's home]
We have that carpet sale this weekend... I bet I don't sell four bolts!
Gloria Sykes was there and she's going to tell everybody about this.
[pause]
[Dinky says nothing]
Don't you have anything to say?
About the carpet sale or Gloria Sykes?
Once when I was six and a quarter, Mrs. Bosetti and I sat down and we talked.
So, what happened?
Well... I told her I preferred books to dolls, boots to ballet slippers and that my idea of a family vacation was for all of us to go work on the Alaskan pipeline.

[discussing her adoptive mother]
She told everyone she thought she had Rosemary's baby. She had a thing about that movie.
